studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study meets all inclusion criteria: it uses task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma probing cooperation/trust), enrolled healthy adult participants (N=20 males, age range 21–37), and reports whole-brain, voxelwise univariate task-evoked group-level results (one-sample t-tests, flexible factorial analyses; FWE cluster-corrected maps and tables of activations). Healthy-group effects are reported and generalized to the healthy sample (not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses). No exclusion criteria are violated (not an ROI-only, resting-state, or non-empirical paper; ages within 17–65). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.
studies.full_text_path: /data/alejandro/projects/autonima-results/social-processing/ace_scrape/articles/html/The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience/30455187.html

studies.title: The Social Brain Automatically Predicts Others' Future Mental States.
studies.abstract: Social life requires people to predict the future: people must anticipate others' thoughts, feelings, and actions to interact with them successfully. The theory of predictive coding suggests that the social brain may meet this need by automatically predicting others' social futures. If so, when representing others' current mental state, the brain should already start representing their future states. To test this hypothesis, we used fMRI to measure female and male human participants' neural representations of mental states. Representational similarity analysis revealed that neural patterns associated with mental states currently under consideration resembled patterns of likely future states more so than patterns of unlikely future states. This effect manifested in activity across the social brain network and in medial prefrontal cortex in particular. Repetition suppression analysis also supported the social predictive coding hypothesis: considering mental states presented in predictable sequences reduced activity in the precuneus relative to unpredictable sequences. In addition to demonstrating that the brain makes automatic predictions of others' social futures, the results also demonstrate that the brain leverages a 3D representational space to make these predictions. Proximity between mental states on the psychological dimensions of rationality, social impact, and valence explained much of the association between state-specific neural pattern similarity and state transition likelihood. Together, these findings suggest that the way the brain represents the social present gives people an automatic glimpse of the social future.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining neural representations of others' mental states (social cognition) in human participants. No clinical populations mentioned; likely healthy adults. Abstract lacks explicit ages, so include for full-text to confirm participant age/health.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition in healthy adults (N=29 scanned, 1 excluded; final N=28; ages 18–22), using a mentalizing/social task (rating others’ mental states). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses: univariate repetition-suppression parametric modulators entered into voxelwise one-sample t-tests with correction via permutation TFCE (significant posterior precuneus cluster reported with MNI coordinates and p_corrected), satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map. Although multivariate RSA/searchlight analyses are also used, the presence of corrected whole-brain univariate results from the healthy sample meets the inclusion criteria (healthy adults, task fMRI, and whole-brain group-level univariate maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Hierarchical Brain Network for Face and Voice Integration of Emotion Expression.
studies.abstract: The brain has separate specialized computational units to process faces and voices located in occipital and temporal cortices. However, humans seamlessly integrate signals from the faces and voices of others for optimal social interaction. How are emotional expressions, when delivered by different sensory modalities (faces and voices), integrated in the brain? In this study, we characterized the brains' response to faces, voices, and combined face-voice information (congruent, incongruent), which varied in expression (neutral, fearful). Using a whole-brain approach, we found that only the right posterior superior temporal sulcus (rpSTS) responded more to bimodal stimuli than to face or voice alone but only when the stimuli contained emotional expression. Face- and voice-selective regions of interest, extracted from independent functional localizers, similarly revealed multisensory integration in the face-selective rpSTS only; further, this was the only face-selective region that also responded significantly to voices. Dynamic causal modeling revealed that the rpSTS receives unidirectional information from the face-selective fusiform face area, and voice-selective temporal voice area, with emotional expression affecting the connection strength. Our study promotes a hierarchical model of face and voice integration, with convergence in the rpSTS, and that such integration depends on the (emotional) salience of the stimuli.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating perception and integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—clearly social-perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is primary empirical research (not a review).
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=24, mean age 26) investigating social-related processing (integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate voxelwise analyses (FWE-corrected maps and peak coordinates) demonstrating bimodal vs. unimodal effects in rpSTS and other whole-brain contrasts, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Independent localizers and ROI/DCM analyses are included but whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (only ROI/connectivity with no whole-brain results; non-healthy sample; non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Neural processing of the own child's facial emotions in mothers with a history of early life maltreatment.
studies.abstract: Early life maltreatment (ELM) has long-lasting effects on social interaction. When interacting with their own child, women with ELM often report difficulties in parenting and show reduced maternal sensitivity. Sensitive maternal behavior requires the recognition of the child's emotional state depicted in its facial emotions. Based on previous studies, it can be expected that ELM affects the neural processing of facial emotions by altering activation patterns in parts of the brain's empathy and mentalizing networks. However, so far studies have focused on the processing of standardized, adult facial emotions. Therefore, the current study investigated the impact of ELM on the processing of one's own child's facial emotions using functional magnetic resonance imaging. To achieve this, 27 mothers with and 26 mothers without a history of ELM (all without current mental disorders and psychopharmacological treatment) took part in an emotional face recognition paradigm with happy, sad, and neutral faces of their own and an unknown primary school-aged child of the same age and sex. We found elevated activations in regions of the mentalizing (superior temporal sulcus, precuneus) and mirror neuron (inferior parietal lobule) networks as well as in the visual face processing network (cuneus, middle temporal gyrus) in mothers with ELM compared to the non-maltreated mothers in response to happy faces of their own child. This suggests a more effortful processing and cognitive empathic mentalizing of the own child's facial happiness in mothers with ELM. Future research should address whether this might indicate a compensatory recruitment of mentalizing capacities to maintain maternal sensitivity.
studies.journal: European archives of psychiatry and clinical neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using an emotional face recognition task involving mothers’ perception of their own child’s facial emotions — a social-related process (attachment/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adult mothers (no current mental disorders). No exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of social processing (maternal perception of child facial emotions) in adult participants. The sample includes a healthy control group of adult mothers (no current mental disorders) reported separately. The paper reports univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., happy>neutral, own>unknown) with voxelwise FWE-corrected results across groups and for each group separately (including a control-group familiarity effect in medial frontal gyrus), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain group-level maps generalizable to healthy adults. The task probes social constructs (perception/understanding of others). Although one group comprises mothers with early life maltreatment, healthy-control results are presented separately; analyses are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only approaches. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Thinking about the past to shape the present: neural activation during the recall of relationship episodes.
studies.abstract: Reflecting on oneself and others in relationships is an ability that is central to our social existence. Specifically, considering formative autobiographical experiences in relationships may contribute to more flexibility in perceiving, as well as in shaping present relationships. Reflecting on such experiences mobilizes different social cognitive and affective processes. We aim to explore the neural basis of these processes. With a newly developed functional magnetic imaging (fMRI) task, we investigated brain activation in 35 healthy individuals during recall of relationship episodes involving themselves or others. We found that recalling formative episodes involving themselves modulated brain activity in the right parahippocampus, left precuneus, bilateral fusiform gyrus, bilateral insula, and left presupplementary motor area. These areas are involved in memory processes, self-generated thought, and affective experience. The recall of relationship episodes involving others led to similar activation patterns. Our results underscore the close link between self-reflection, understanding others, and memory processes and emphasize the role of affective dimensions for self-relevant experiences. They contribute to a growing body of research on neural mechanisms involved in complex social cognitive processes decisive for our capacity to navigate our social environment.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with 35 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (recall of relationship episodes about self and others), addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met in abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (recall of formative relationship episodes involving self and others) in healthy adults (n=35, mean age 33.85, no mental disorders). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (self-relevant>control, other>control) analyzed with SPM12 and FDR-corrected cluster inference; results are reported in tables and figures with cluster coordinates. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: Human behavioural discrimination of human, chimpanzee and macaque affective vocalisations is reflected by the neural response in the superior temporal sulcus.
studies.abstract: Accurate perception of the emotional content of vocalisations is essential for successful social communication and interaction. However, it is not clear whether our ability to perceive emotional cues from vocal signals is specific to human signals, or can be applied to other species' vocalisations. Here, we address this issue by evaluating the perception and neural response to affective vocalisations from different primate species (humans, chimpanzees and macaques). We found that the ability of human participants to discriminate emotional valence varied as a function of phylogenetic distance between species. Participants were most accurate at discriminating the emotional valence of human vocalisations, followed by chimpanzee vocalisations. They were, however, unable to accurately discriminate the valence of macaque vocalisations. Next, we used fMRI to compare human brain responses to human, chimpanzee and macaque vocalisations. We found that regions in the superior temporal lobe that are closely associated with the perception of complex auditory signals, showed a graded response to affective vocalisations from different species with the largest response to human vocalisations, an intermediate response to chimpanzees, and the smallest response to macaques. Together, these results suggest that neural correlates of differences in the perception of different primate affective vocalisations are found in auditory regions of the human brain and correspond to the phylogenetic distances between the species.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used to measure human brain responses while participants judged affective vocalisations (social communication). Study involves healthy adult human participants and addresses social perception; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=19, mean age 25.9) that investigates perception of affective vocalisations—a social communication task (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked analyses (e.g., species contrast human > chimpanzee > macaque) with statistical maps, MNI coordinates, tables and figures (whole-brain results reported at p<.001). It is not ROI-only, seed/connectivity-only, or resting-state, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Dissimilar processing of emotional facial expressions in human and monkey temporal cortex.
studies.abstract: Emotional facial expressions play an important role in social communication across primates. Despite major progress made in our understanding of categorical information processing such as for objects and faces, little is known, however, about how the primate brain evolved to process emotional cues. In this study, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to compare the processing of emotional facial expressions between monkeys and humans. We used a 2×2×2 factorial design with species (human and monkey), expression (fear and chewing) and configuration (intact versus scrambled) as factors. At the whole brain level, neural responses to conspecific emotional expressions were anatomically confined to the superior temporal sulcus (STS) in humans. Within the human STS, we found functional subdivisions with a face-selective right posterior STS area that also responded to emotional expressions of other species and a more anterior area in the right middle STS that responded specifically to human emotions. Hence, we argue that the latter region does not show a mere emotion-dependent modulation of activity but is primarily driven by human emotional facial expressions. Conversely, in monkeys, emotional responses appeared in earlier visual cortex and outside face-selective regions in inferior temporal cortex that responded also to multiple visual categories. Within monkey IT, we also found areas that were more responsive to conspecific than to non-conspecific emotional expressions but these responses were not as specific as in human middle STS. Overall, our results indicate that human STS may have developed unique properties to deal with social cues such as emotional expressions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examines processing of emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception) in humans and monkeys; humans are healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). This is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, and meets the review’s social-related task criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study that includes a healthy adult sample (n=23, ages 24–34) and uses a social-related task (perception of dynamic facial emotional expressions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (group significance maps, cluster-corrected results, and stereotactic coordinates in supplementary tables) for task-evoked contrasts in the healthy human participants. Results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and ROI analyses are supplementary; not limited to ROI-only or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults focused on social processing.

studies.title: Inter-subject synchrony as an index of functional specialization in early childhood.
studies.abstract: Early childhood is a time of significant change within multiple cognitive domains including social cognition, memory, executive function, and language; however, the corresponding neural changes remain poorly understood. This is likely due to the difficulty in acquiring artifact-free functional MRI data during complex task-based or unconstrained resting-state experiments in young children. In addition, task-based and resting state experiments may not capture dynamic real-world processing. Here we overcome both of these challenges through use of naturalistic viewing (i.e., passively watching a movie in the scanner) combined with inter-subject neural synchrony to examine functional specialization within 4- and 6-year old children. Using a novel and stringent crossed random effect statistical analysis, we find that children show more variable patterns of activation compared to adults, particularly within regions of the default mode network (DMN). In addition, we found partial evidence that child-to-adult synchrony increased as a function of age within a DMN region: the temporoparietal junction. Our results suggest age-related differences in functional brain organization within a cross-sectional sample during an ecologically valid context and demonstrate that neural synchrony during naturalistic viewing fMRI can be used to examine functional specialization during early childhood - a time when neural and cognitive systems are in flux.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: The abstract reports fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing and compares children to adults, but does not specify adult age range (17–65) or explicitly state that the movie/task targeted social-related processing. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study uses fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing (Toy Story), a stimulus with clear social-cognitive demands (theory of mind, social interactions). The sample includes a healthy adult group (final N=21 adults) within the target age range and reported adult-group results separately. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level statistical maps of inter-subject correlation (within-group inter-SC maps and Adult vs. Child contrasts) with multiple-comparison correction and peak coordinates, which are whole-brain task-evoked effects generalizable to healthy adults. Although the analysis uses inter-subject correlation rather than a traditional GLM, the reported group-level voxel/nodewise statistical maps satisfy the criterion of whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy/control group. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Social pain and social gain in the adolescent brain: A common neural circuitry underlying both positive and negative social evaluation.
studies.abstract: Social interaction inherently involves the subjective evaluation of cues salient to social inclusion and exclusion. Testifying to the importance of such social cues, parts of the neural system dedicated to the detection of physical pain, the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) and anterior insula (AI), have been shown to be equally sensitive to the detection of social pain experienced after social exclusion. However, recent work suggests that this dACC-AI matrix may index any socially pertinent information. We directly tested the hypothesis that the dACC-AI would respond to cues of both inclusion and exclusion, using a novel social feedback fMRI paradigm in a population-derived sample of adolescents. We show that the dACC and left AI are commonly activated by feedback cues of inclusion and exclusion. Our findings suggest that theoretical accounts of the dACC-AI network as a neural alarm system restricted within the social domain to the processing of signals of exclusion require significant revision.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social feedback (inclusion/exclusion) in a population-derived adolescent sample, directly relevant to social processing. Abstract does not report participant ages, so it is unclear whether subjects fall within the review age range (17–65). Include for full-text review to verify ages and eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study using a social feedback task (social inclusion/exclusion) in a healthy sample (N=56 analyzed; ages 17–20), which falls within the review’s adult range (17–65). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunctions) with voxelwise familywise-error correction and provides peak coordinates and conjunction maps. Analyses are reported for the healthy cohort (results not limited to a narrow subgroup), and are not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Age-related changes to the neural correlates of social evaluation.
studies.abstract: Recent work suggests the existence of a specialized neural system underlying social processing that may be relatively spared with age, unlike pervasive aging-related decline occurring in many cognitive domains. We investigated how neural mechanisms underlying social evaluation are engaged with age, and how age-related changes to socioemotional goals affect recruitment of regions within this network. In a functional MRI study, 15 young and 15 older adults formed behavior-based impressions of individuals. They also responded to a prompt that was interpersonally meaningful, social but interpersonally irrelevant, or non-social. Both age groups engaged regions implicated in mentalizing and impression formation when making social relative to non-social evaluations, including dorsal and ventral medial prefrontal cortices, precuneus, and temporoparietal junction. Older adults had increased activation over young in right temporal pole when making social relative to non-social evaluations, suggesting reliance on past experiences when evaluating others. Young adults had greater activation than old in posterior cingulate gyrus when making interpersonally irrelevant, compared to interpersonally meaningful, evaluations, potentially reflecting enhanced valuation of this information. The findings demonstrate the age-related preservation of the neural correlates underlying social evaluation, and suggest that functioning in these regions might be mediated by age-related changes in socioemotional goals.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social evaluation (impression formation) in healthy young and older adults; task targets social processing (perception/understanding of others). At least one group (young adults) falls within 17–65. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation (social-meaningful, social-irrelevant, non-social conditions). It reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant) with corrected cluster thresholds and tables/figures of peak coordinates for the healthy participant groups. A healthy younger adult group (age 20–29) is analyzed and reported separately, meeting the 17–65 age requirement. The paper does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses and presents whole-brain task activation maps/generalizable effects for the healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria appear violated.

studies.title: Aging minds and twisting attitudes: an fMRI investigation of age differences in inhibiting prejudice.
studies.abstract: Cognitive capacity is believed to decline with age, but it is not known whether this decline extends to tasks involving social cognition. In the current study, social neuroscience methodologies were used to examine the effects of age-related cognitive decline on older adults' abilities to engage regulatory mechanisms (which are typically impaired by normal aging) to inhibit negative reactions to stigmatized individuals. Older and young adults were presented with images of stigmatized individuals (e.g., individuals with amputations, substance abusers) and of normal controls while they underwent functional magnetic resonance imaging. All participants were also given a battery of tests to assess their executive function capacity. Young adults showed more activity in areas associated with empathy (i.e., medial prefrontal cortex) than did older adults when viewing stigmatized faces. By contrast, older adults with relatively preserved levels of executive function had heightened activity in areas previously implicated in emotion regulation (i.e., lateral prefrontal cortex) as compared to other groups. These results suggest that although cognitive decline may interfere with older adults' attitudes toward stigmatized individuals, older adults with relatively preserved cognitive function may utilize different strategies to compensate for these deficits.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while participants viewed stigmatized individuals—a social perception/understanding of others task. Includes healthy young adult group (young and older adults), so meets age criterion. Study investigates social cognition (empathy, regulation) in healthy adults and is not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition (inhibiting prejudice/perception of stigmatized others) that reports group-level task-evoked activations. The sample includes healthy young and older adult groups (young adults fall within the 17–65 range), and the abstract describes whole-brain activations (e.g., medial and lateral prefrontal cortex) associated with task conditions, indicating univariate voxelwise contrasts rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Results are reported separately for healthy groups (young vs. older adults) and are generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Childhood maternal support and social capital moderate the regulatory impact of social relationships in adulthood.
studies.abstract: For this functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study, we assessed the impact of early social experiences on the social regulation of neural threat responding in a sample of 22 individuals that have been followed for over a decade. At 13 years old, a multidimensional measure of neighborhood quality was derived from parental reports. Three measures of neighborhood quality were used to estimate social capital-the level of trust, reciprocity, cooperation, and shared resources within a community. At 16 years old, an observational measure of maternal emotional support behavior was derived from a mother/child social interaction task. At 24 years old, participants were asked to visit our neuroimaging facility with an opposite-sex platonic friend. During their MRI visit, participants were subjected to the threat of electric shock while holding their friend's hand, the hand of an anonymous opposite-sex experimenter, or no hand at all. Higher adolescent maternal support corresponded with less threat-related activation during friend handholding, but not during the stranger or alone conditions, in the bilateral orbitofrontal cortex, inferior frontal gyrus and left insula. Higher neighborhood social capital corresponded with less threat-related activation during friend hand-holding in the superior frontal gyrus, supplementary motor cortex, insula, putamen and thalamus; but low childhood capital corresponded with less threat-related activation during stranger handholding in the same regions. Exploratory analyses suggest that this latter result is due to the increased threat responsiveness during stranger handholding among low social capital individuals, even during safety cues. Overall, early maternal support behavior and high neighborhood quality may potentiate soothing by relational partners, and low neighborhood quality may decrease the overall regulatory impact of access to social resources in adulthood.
studies.journal: International journal of psychophysiology : official journal of the International Organization of Psychophysiology
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study using a social regulation task (hand-holding with friend vs stranger vs alone) performed in adult participants (~24 years). It examines social-affiliative processes in healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=22, mean age 23.6) using a social-affiliation task (friend/stranger/alone hand-holding during threat). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (threat vs. safe contrast during the alone condition) to define functional ROIs using FSL cluster-wise tests (Z>2.3, cluster p<.05) and provides coordinates/cluster information (Table 1) and group-level contrasts. Results are task-evoked univariate activation maps from the healthy adult sample and not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical groups. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult, task-based fMRI with whole-brain group-level results.

studies.title: Higher or lower? The functional anatomy of perceived allocentric social hierarchies.
studies.abstract: The perception and judgement of social hierarchies forms an integral part of social cognition. Hierarchical judgements can be either self-referential or allocentric (pertaining to two or more external agents). In psychiatric conditions such as dissocial personality disorder and schizophrenia, the impact of hierarchies may be problematic. We sought to elucidate the brain regions involved in judging allocentric social hierarchies. Twenty-two healthy male subjects underwent three fMRI scans. During scanning, subjects answered questions concerning visually-presented target pairs of human individual's relative superiority within a specific social hierarchy or their perceived degree of social alliance (i.e., whether they were "friends or enemies"). Subjects also made judgements relating to target pairs' age, gender and fame to control for confounding factors and performed a baseline numerical task. Response times increased in line with hypothesized ascending executive load. Both social hierarchy and social alliance judgements activated left ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (VLPFC), left dorsal inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) and bilateral fusiform gyri. In addition, social alliance judgements activated right dorsal IFG and medial prefrontal cortex. When compared directly with social alliance, social hierarchy judgements activated left orbitofrontal cortex. Detecting the presence of social hierarchies and judging other's relative standing within them implicates the cognitive executive, in particular the VLPFC. Our finding informs accounts of 'normal' social cognition but our method also provides a means of probing the dissocial brain in personality disorder and schizophrenia where executive function may be dysfunctional.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where healthy participants performed social hierarchy/alliance judgments (social cognition). Not a review. Abstract does not report participants' ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed on age criterion from abstract alone—include for full-text review to verify ages and other details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgments). Participants: 22 healthy adult males (mean age 24.2), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked SPM analyses with coordinates and family-wise error (FWE) correction (p<0.05) for multiple contrasts (e.g., social alliance vs number-equal; social hierarchy vs fame/age/gender/number), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Results are presented as tables of coordinates and figures and are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and includes original fMRI data. Although only male subjects were studied, a healthy adult group is reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: An fMRI study of violations of social expectations: when people are not who we expect them to be.
studies.abstract: The current study examines the effect of violations of social expectancies on the neural substrates of person perception. In an event-related fMRI experiment, participants were presented with the photographs of either Republican or Democrat politicians paired with either typical Republican or Democrat political views (e.g., "wants a smaller government" or "wants liberal supreme court judges"). Subjects were asked to form an impression of the targets using information about both their political affiliation and their political views. Of interest was the contrast between stereotypically congruent trials and stereotypically incongruent trials. The results reveal that brain regions previously involved in mentalizing (i.e., temporoparietal junction and medial prefrontal cortex) are preferentially recruited when viewing incongruent social targets.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI examining person perception/mentalizing during social expectation violations fits the review objective (social-related processing). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study of impression formation (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (N=18, ages 19–30). The task is social (political affiliation congruency) and probes social expectancy violations. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (random-effects incongruent > congruent contrast) with cluster results and FDR-corrected activations listed in Table 1 (MNI coordinates provided) in addition to ROI analyses. Participants are within the 17–65 range and results pertain to the healthy control sample. The study is empirical and reports original task-evoked whole-brain activation maps generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Brain mechanisms for processing affective touch.
studies.abstract: Despite the crucial role of touch in social development, there is very little functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) research on brain mechanisms underlying social touch processing. The "skin as a social organ" hypothesis is supported by the discovery of C-tactile (CT) nerves that are present in hairy skin and project to the insular cortex. CT-fibers respond specifically well to slow, gentle touch such as that which occurs during close social interactions. Given the social significance of such touch researchers have proposed that the CT-system represents an evolutionarily conserved mechanism important for normative social development. However, it is currently unknown whether brain regions other than the insula are involved in processing CT-targeted touch. In the current fMRI study, we sought to characterize the brain regions involved in the perception of CT-supported affective touch. Twenty-two healthy adults received manual brush strokes to either the arm or palm. A direct contrast of the blood-oxygenation-level-dependent (BOLD) response to gentle brushing of the arm and palm revealed the involvement of a network of brain regions, in addition to the posterior insula, during CT-targeted affective touch to the arm. This network included areas known to be involved in social perception and social cognition, including the right posterior superior temporal sulcus and the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC)/dorso anterior cingulate cortex (dACC). Connectivity analyses with an mPFC/dACC seed revealed coactivation with the left insula and amygdala during arm touch. These findings characterize a network of brain regions beyond the insula involved in coding CT-targeted affective touch.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adults (n=22) using affective/social touch task probing social perception/cognition (CT-targeted touch); directly addresses social processing; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of affective (social) touch in healthy adults (N=22; ages 19–35). The task probes socio-affective processing (CT-targeted gentle touch), directly relevant to social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and social perception). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM analyses (arm>baseline, palm>baseline, arm>palm) with thresholding and tables of peak coordinates and cluster sizes, satisfying the whole-brain univariate task-evoked map requirement for the healthy group. Behavioral data for the healthy sample are reported separately. The study is empirical, uses task fMRI (not only ROI or connectivity), and provides whole-brain results generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: External motivation to avoid prejudice alters neural responses to targets varying in race and status.
studies.abstract: Those who are high in external motivation to respond without prejudice (EMS) tend to focus on non-racial attributes when describing others. This fMRI study examined the neural processing of race and an alternative yet stereotypically relevant attribute (viz., socioeconomic status: SES) as a function of the perceiver's EMS. Sixty-one White participants privately formed impressions of Black and White faces ascribed with high or low SES. Analyses focused on regions supporting race- and status-based reward/salience (NAcc), evaluation (VMPFC) and threat/relevance (amygdala). Consistent with previous findings from the literature on status-based evaluation, we observed greater neural responses to high-status (vs low-status) targets in all regions of interest when participants were relatively low in EMS. In contrast, we observed the opposite pattern when participants were relatively high in EMS. Notably, all effects were independent of target race. In summary, White perceivers' race-related motivations similarly altered their neural responses to the SES of Black and White targets. Specifically, the findings suggest that EMS may attenuate the positive value and/or salience of high status in a mixed-race context. Findings are discussed in the context of the stereotypic relationship between race and SES.
keywords: external motivation to respond without prejudice
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of Black and White faces varying in SES) conducted in 61 healthy White adult participants. Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social perception (impression formation of others varying by race and socioeconomic status), conducted in healthy adult participants (60 adult males, mean age 23.8). The task is a task-evoked, event-related impression-formation paradigm using faces (social-related processing). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain second-level GLMs and exploratory whole-brain regression results (clusters for the main effect of status and a VMPFC cluster), in addition to ROI analyses. Whole-brain task activation maps/coordinates are described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (only ROIs, only connectivity, non-healthy sample, or no whole-brain maps) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Cerebral correlates and statistical criteria of cross-modal face and voice integration.
studies.abstract: Perception of faces and voices plays a prominent role in human social interaction, making multisensory integration of cross-modal speech a topic of great interest in cognitive neuroscience. How to define potential sites of multisensory integration using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is currently under debate, with three statistical criteria frequently used (e.g., super-additive, max and mean criteria). In the present fMRI study, 20 participants were scanned in a block design under three stimulus conditions: dynamic unimodal face, unimodal voice and bimodal face-voice. Using this single dataset, we examine all these statistical criteria in an attempt to define loci of face-voice integration. While the super-additive and mean criteria essentially revealed regions in which one of the unimodal responses was a deactivation, the max criterion appeared stringent and only highlighted the left hippocampus as a potential site of face- voice integration. Psychophysiological interaction analysis showed that connectivity between occipital and temporal cortices increased during bimodal compared to unimodal conditions. We concluded that, when investigating multisensory integration with fMRI, all these criteria should be used in conjunction with manipulation of stimulus signal-to-noise ratio and/or cross-modal congruency.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing face and voice perception tasks (unimodal and bimodal), directly addressing social communication/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults. Age range not specified but participants appear to be healthy adults; full text can confirm ages if needed.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=20) using a task involving face and voice stimuli (socially relevant perception of others). The study used a block design with unimodal and bimodal conditions and reports group-level univariate whole-brain results (mentions regions identified by super-additive, max and mean criteria, and highlights hippocampus and occipital/temporal cortices), meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although psychophysiological interaction (connectivity) analyses were also performed, the paper includes univariate task-evoked maps, not ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participant age range is within healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: How do we empathize with someone who is not like us? A functional magnetic resonance imaging study.
studies.abstract: Previous research on the neural underpinnings of empathy has been limited to affective situations experienced in a similar way by an observer and a target individual. In daily life we also interact with people whose responses to affective stimuli can be very different from our own. How do we understand the affective states of these individuals? We used functional magnetic resonance imaging to assess how participants empathize with the feelings of patients who reacted with no pain to surgical procedures but with pain to a soft touch. Empathy for pain of these patients activated the same areas (insula, medial/anterior cingulate cortex) as empathy for persons who responded to painful stimuli in the same way as the observer. Empathy in a situation that was aversive only for the observer but neutral for the patient recruited areas involved in self-other distinction (dorsomedial prefrontal cortex) and cognitive control (right inferior frontal cortex). In addition, effective connectivity between the latter and areas implicated in affective processing was enhanced. This suggests that inferring the affective state of someone who is not like us can rely upon the same neural structures as empathy for someone who is similar to us. When strong emotional response tendencies exist though, these tendencies have to be overcome by executive functions. Our results demonstrate that the fronto-cortical attention network is crucially involved in this process, corroborating that empathy is a flexible phenomenon which involves both automatic and controlled cognitive mechanisms. Our findings have important implications for the understanding and promotion of empathy, demonstrating that regulation of one's egocentric perspective is crucial for understanding others.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining empathy (perception/understanding of others) — a social-processing task — in human participants. Abstract indicates healthy adult participants and reports neural activations during the task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (empathy/perspective-taking). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Pain > No Pain: Similar others; No Pain: Dissimilar > Similar) with cluster results and figures/tables, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. Seed/PPI analyses are present but are not the sole reported results. No exclusion criteria apply (not resting-state only, not clinical-only, includes healthy adult whole-brain maps). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: From agents to objects: sexist attitudes and neural responses to sexualized targets.
studies.abstract: Agency attribution is a hallmark of mind perception; thus, diminished attributions of agency may disrupt social-cognition processes typically elicited by human targets. The current studies examine the effect of perceivers' sexist attitudes on associations of agency with, and neural responses to, images of sexualized and clothed men and women. In Study 1, male (but not female) participants with higher hostile sexism scores more quickly associated sexualized women with first-person action verbs ("handle") and clothed women with third-person action verbs ("handles") than the inverse, as compared to their less sexist peers. In Study 2, hostile sexism correlated negatively with activation of regions associated with mental state attribution-medial prefrontal cortex, posterior cingulate, temporal poles-but only when viewing sexualized women. Heterosexual men best recognized images of sexualized female bodies (but not faces), as compared with other targets' bodies; however, neither face nor body recognition was related to hostile sexism, suggesting that the fMRI findings are not explained by more or less attention to sexualized female targets. Diminished mental state attribution is not unique to targets that people prefer to avoid, as in dehumanization of stigmatized people. The current studies demonstrate that appetitive social targets may elicit a similar response depending on perceivers' attitudes toward them.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study 2 uses fMRI to examine neural responses in regions associated with mental-state attribution (mPFC, PCC, temporal poles) while viewing social targets, fitting 'Perception and Understanding of Others'. Human adult participants (heterosexual men reported) are described; not a review. Full text may be needed for exact age range/sample details, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=21 heterosexual male undergraduates, ages within 17–65). The task probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, mental state attribution) via passive viewing of sexualized and clothed male and female targets. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked activation analyses (exploratory whole-brain contrasts with voxelwise threshold p<.001 and AlphaSim cluster correction; results presented in Tables/Figures), not ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Healthy-group whole-brain contrasts and correlations with hostile sexism are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

abstract_screening_results.reason: The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. While it examines social variables (peer/parent relationships) as predictors, there is no social-processing task performed during scanning, so it does not meet the task-based fMRI inclusion criterion.

Participants are healthy adults; study is original research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI examining neural processing of race and socioeconomic status during social evaluation of faces in 61 white male participants. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI was conducted in 16 healthy adult volunteers viewing a movie of verbal and non-verbal social interactions, examining neural responses to social perception/interpretation. This directly fits the review objective; not a review or meta-analysis.

Participant health/age not specified in abstract, but likely healthy adults; insufficient explicit detail warrants inclusion for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion; full-text can confirm participant ages/health but abstract strongly indicates healthy adult sample.

Participants appear to be healthy adults and the study is empirical (not a review). Age not specified in abstract, so moderate confidence; include for full-text review.

However, the abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Primary data fMRI study investigating perception of social interactions using point-light and moving-shape stimuli; participants appear to be healthy adults performing a social-related task (interaction vs non-interaction, competition vs cooperation). fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 25–50) but the task (viewing erotic pictures/videos) is not clearly described as a social-related task in the abstract. fMRI study with 36 healthy adult subjects (within 17–65). Participants observed social interactions probing social cognition (cooperativity, affectivity). Empirical fMRI data collected during a social-related task; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing collaborative vs. individual communicative tasks—addresses social communication/perception of others. Not a review. Abstract omits participant ages, but meets core inclusion criteria; include for full-text to confirm age range and details.

Original fMRI research examining neural responses to person-related and other social concepts (concrete and abstract social terms) in human participants; directly addresses social-related processing. fMRI study with 20 (presumably healthy adult) participants performing a social decision-making task (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing Theory of Mind/social cognition. Adult healthy participants (monogamous vs non-monogamous men) viewed romantic and sexual stimuli; neural activation to social/affiliative (romantic) stimuli was measured. This matches fMRI social-related task in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

Original empirical fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/mentalizing (social cognition) using tasks probing others’ beliefs and motivations. Involves healthy adult participants and is not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI studies.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults using a social interaction task (telling jokes to make a listener laugh) that probes self-related and other-related processing (mPFC, auditory cortex, ventral striatum). It directly addresses social-related processing and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Functional MRI was used during an observe/imitate emotional faces task — a social perception/understanding of others paradigm — in healthy adult participants (final N=20). Not a review/meta-analysis and matches review objective.

fMRI experiment (n=17) involved mentalising/theory-of-mind tasks (social cognition) vs factual memory in human participants; appears to involve healthy adult subjects and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 50 healthy adult participants performing retrieval of biographical/person knowledge—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.

Abstract describes neural mechanisms of social information sharing (social-related processing) and reports two studies; however it does not explicitly state fMRI or participant ages. fMRI study of social cognition (mental state/mentalizing judgments) in healthy adult participants. Task involves social-related processing with neural measures; not a review/meta-analysis. fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social cognition (cooperation vs competition) in human participants; not a review. Abstract reports neural-level analyses (dynamic causal modeling) of empathy and mentalizing in a large sample (N=178), indicating neuroimaging of social processes. fMRI study in adult participants using a social-related task (socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation with a psychotherapist) assessing attachment and social functioning. Appears to involve healthy adults and is an original empirical study, not a review — meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study (n=38) used a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) examining social reward and related neural activation (ventral striatum, precuneus). fMRI was conducted while participants performed a social-related task (attending to meaning of symbolic artifacts and viewing own vs others’ models), targeting social cognition in presumably healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

Primary fMRI study in healthy adults performing a visually based social judgment task (evaluation of social dominance in faces), directly addressing social cognitive processing. Functional MRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social processing (responses to unexpected social vs non-social events) in human participants. This addresses the review objective. Original fMRI experiment in healthy human participants investigating person perception and mentalising (social cognition). Task pairs bodies/names with trait statements — a social-related task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Eligible for full-text data extraction.

This is an fMRI study of empathy/social cognition in healthy adult participants (20 adults) performing a social-related task (receiving empathic vs unempathic responses). It directly addresses social-related processing and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Task-based fMRI study investigating affective theory of mind (social processing) using a well-established ToM paradigm; 21 healthy adult participants analyzed. fMRI study investigating guilt (a social-emotional/social-cognition process) in human participants, meeting the review topic. Abstract reports dyadic and monadic fMRI during live eye contact—a social interaction task relevant to the review. However, it does not specify participant ages or whether participants were healthy. Insufficient participant detail in abstract; include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants (N=26) learned about others’ generosity (social task) with a non-social control; meets the review objective. Human fMRI study where participants viewed faces of group members while performing a social cognition task; investigates perception/understanding of others and neural correlates. fMRI study examining perception of others (racial in-group/out-group disgust)—a social processing task. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

Primary fMRI study where participants read social vs non-social literary passages during functional neuroimaging, assessing theory-of-mind/social cognition. Not a review/meta-analysis. fMRI study investigating empathy/perspective-taking (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (n=18, within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports a task-based functional MRI study examining affiliative (kinship-related) social scenarios in humans, directly matching the review objective of social processing. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm that at least one group are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study in 19 healthy adult participants viewing naturalistic social stimuli (faces, bodies, emotion, interaction, speech) during task-like movie clips; directly investigates social perception/processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=27) performing a social-related task (observing cooperative vs. affective interactions) probing perception/understanding of others; clearly within review scope and not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study using social-related stimuli (power and love movie clips) in human participants (n=17), examining affiliation/power motivation neural correlates. No indication of clinical sample. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet age criterion.

fMRI study investigating social cognition (simulation and prediction of others' decisions), directly relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others. Abstract does not specify participant demographics or health status; not enough info to confirm age/health, so include for full-text review to verify sample meets criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural and subjective responses to witnessing others’ distress using a socio-affective video task in healthy adult participants; examines social-affective processes (empathy/compassion) and reports task-related brain activation. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI measured brain responses while participants viewed emotional movies and rated valence/arousal, addressing sharing others’ emotions and understanding intentions/actions (perception/understanding of others). Abstract implies healthy participants but does not list ages; relevant to social-processing objective, include for full-text verification of participant ages and details.

Primary research using fMRI to examine neural representations of self vs. familiar/unfamiliar others during threat, addressing social-related constructs (empathy, self–other perception) in human participants. Fits inclusion criteria (functional MRI, social task, healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract states this is a review of model-based approaches rather than a report of primary fMRI data in human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; no primary fMRI study in healthy adults is described.

fMRI study with 51 healthy adult participants performing affective speech classification (emotion inference/Theory of Mind), a social-cognition task. Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (forming and updating impressions of others from faces and behaviors). Directly addresses perception/understanding of others; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult women performing a self–other referential processing task (viewing self/other images and valenced trait adjectives), addressing self-referential and social processing. Meets inclusion (social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review.

Human fMRI study of empathic decision-making (social processing), where participants made choices for themselves and for others; reports neural activity in vmPFC and IPL related to empathy and social cognition. Involves healthy adult participants and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social working memory task examining brain activation related to social cognitive load in humans. It targets social cognition in healthy adults (implied), is empirical (not a review), and fits the review objective.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social task (perception of in-group vs out-group actions). Directly investigates social perception/processing during scanning and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study investigating emotional prosody comprehension—a social communication task—examining neural correlates. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI of social processing; not a review. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age/healthy criteria.

This article is a review synthesizing lesion, single-unit, and imaging studies rather than reporting original fMRI data collected during social tasks in human participants. It is a review paper, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study using point-light displays of human locomotion addresses perception of others/biological motion (a social-related process involving STS). Abstract does not state participant health status or ages, so full text needed to confirm healthy adults 17–65; include for full-text review.

Primary research using real-time fMRI while participants played the ultimatum game (a social decision-making interaction). Involves healthy volunteers (adults) and examines social-related processing (understanding/predicting others' decisions). Not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social exclusion (social cognition) using an interactive ball-toss task. Abstract describes neural responses to peer exclusion but does not specify participant ages or explicitly state health status; insufficient detail to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (human-human competition requiring Theory of Mind). Meets inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults); not a review.

fMRI study where human participants performed an emotional classification task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy-only sample; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility and extract participant details.

fMRI study in which participants made judgments about social categories (stereotypes), a social-cognition task matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health, but abstract provides clear evidence of social-related fMRI processing.

fMRI study investigating social cognition (positivity motivation) comparing close vs. non-close others; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults (though exact ages not reported). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in adults; include for full-text review to confirm sample age range and health status.

fMRI study of social processing (eye contact and spontaneous mimicry) in human participants. It reports neural mechanisms in mPFC/STS/mirror system and is empirical (not a review). Participants are described as human (n=20) consistent with healthy adults; if age details are missing, include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants (n=15) viewed and rated short movie-clips of social interactions—directly addresses social processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study where human participants (n=25) performed prosocial decisions toward family—a social cognition task involving mentalizing and self-control. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This study used EEG, not functional MRI, and investigated diagnostic EEG measures in Alzheimer’s disease versus controls rather than social-related processing tasks in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the fMRI and task-related inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in normal adult volunteers using videos of positive and negative social encounters—directly assesses social processing in healthy adults (age range consistent with 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Original fMRI study in healthy adults examining social interaction vs solitary context during episodic memory tasks (social processing). Meets inclusion (social-related fMRI in healthy adults); not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info.

fMRI study examining dmPFC activity during impression formation—a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but lacks explicit age/health details; include for full-text review to confirm.

3T BOLD fMRI study in 29 healthy subjects (14F/15M) during processing of humorous cartoons — a social-cognition/emotion task (perception and appraisal of others’ emotions). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm age range and additional details.

Abstract reports an fMRI neuroimaging study examining brain responses to observed social interactions (mirror and mentalizing networks) using point-light displays. This fits the review objective of social processing in humans. The abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Study used resting-state fMRI connectivity analyses rather than a task-based fMRI scan involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires participants perform a social-related task during fMRI, so exclude based on abstract information.

Four fMRI experiments (n=98) in healthy adults examining social cognition (self, friends, unknown others), testing closeness/similarity—clearly a social-related task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study examining social gaze effects on action control (social-related processing) in human participants. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects but does not report ages/health explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI was used with healthy adult participants (n=64) performing a social cognition task (inferring others’ preferences vs. own), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract.

fMRI conducted while healthy participants played charades (a social communication task) measuring neural responses during interaction; fits social processing in adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (familiarity judgments of personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces). Addresses perception/understanding of others and social cognition; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

This is a review article (Annual Review) summarizing fMRI and lesion studies rather than reporting original fMRI data on human participants; exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) is met.

fMRI study using a socio-emotional preference task (social preference judgments of human faces), directly addressing social processing. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides clear task and imaging methods meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining empathy/affiliation by having (presumably healthy) participants imagine self, loved-one, and stranger in painful situations—addresses social-related processing (attachment, perception of others) in humans and is not a review.

fMRI study where participants engaged in live face-to-face social interaction and joint attention tasks; reports neural activation in social cognition regions. No indication it is a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages explicitly, but participants appear to be healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm age/health criteria.

fMRI study of charitable donation decisions—a social decision-making task involving social cognition and value computation. Involves healthy adult subjects (not explicitly ages but typical sample). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study using a naturalistic joint-attention/social cognition task (representing what another person sees), examining perception/understanding of others in humans. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study reports an fMRI experiment where healthy participants made social-related judgments (self vs friend personality and memory), matching the review objective. Abstract does not indicate clinical populations; if sample details (age/health) are unclear, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating empathy and social cognition (perception/understanding of others) in humans; no indication of clinical populations. Abstract lacks explicit age range but clearly examines social-related processing in healthy participants, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant details.

Original fMRI study using the Movie for the Assessment of Social Cognition examining Theory of Mind/mental state reasoning (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports task-based fMRI in naturalistic social processing. Participant health and ages not specified—include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65) and sample details.

Abstract describes a behavioral neuropsychological study of patients with frontal and temporo-parietal lesions; no functional MRI was conducted and participants are clinical patients rather than healthy adults performing fMRI social tasks, so it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in 26 healthy adult participants investigating how social context and perceived agency modulate neural responses to others' pain—addresses perception/understanding of others and social interaction. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining audiovisual integration of facial movements and non-verbal vocalizations—clearly a social-communication/perception task. Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant age or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI was used to measure neural responses to masked facial emotions (social-affiliative/attachment processing) in a sample of 51 healthy adults. The task probes perception of others’ emotional signals (social processing). Not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study using the Trust Game examines reciprocity (social cognition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages or clinical status; no exclusion criteria clearly met. Include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).

The study uses fMRI to investigate mental state decoding (Perception and Understanding of Others) in healthy adult participants (native Japanese and white American). It reports neural correlates of social cognition and is an empirical fMRI study (not a review), meeting the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of empathy for pain (affect sharing and self–other distinction) using video stimuli in human participants, addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). fMRI study examining social processing (pupillary exchange/social salience) in human subjects, directly relevant to social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they are healthy adults; therefore include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating social-related auditory perception (social interaction signals) in humans, meeting the review objective. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI study where human participants observed social vs individual actions; investigates social cognition (gaze effects) and reports brain activity (dMPFC). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text confirmation of participant demographics and health status.

Event-related fMRI study explicitly examines responses to social (face) versus non-social targets, directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly say ‘healthy’, so include for full-text review to confirm that at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65) was studied.

fMRI study of social processing (gaze shifts, joint attention) in humans; meets the review objective. Abstract implies behavioural and neural responses in participants (likely healthy adults) but does not state ages/health explicitly—include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (judgments about social groups/individuals) in human participants, not a review. fMRI study investigating social perception (approach with happy/angry expressions) in human participants. Addresses social processing relevant to the review. fMRI study examining perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication/perception of others) in human participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social exchange processing (Wason selection task). Addresses social-related processing and is empirical (not a review). Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants involving social cognition (attribution of intentions to human vs computer‑generated music); reports neural activations in mental-state attribution network. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI in healthy human participants performing social-related tasks (gaze and pointing) probing social communication/Perception of Others. Study reports BOLD responses and neural loci; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was performed in 18 healthy adult participants during a social motor response learning task that involves inferring others' intentions/goals, meeting the review’s social-processing and healthy adult criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Original study used fMRI during an emotion-attribution task (SELF/OTHER) probing empathy and social cognition in human subjects. fMRI study in healthy adults examining self-recognition (face and name), which fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ social processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

Primary research using fMRI during a social interactive task (and non-social control) in human subjects; examines social cognition and in-group/out-group interactions relevant to perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in humans investigating neural processing of social hierarchy (social status), clearly a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others. fMRI study with healthy volunteers performing a social cognition (theory-of-mind) task examining cooperation and deception, which fits the review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study examining observation, imitation, and production of facial expressions and social hand gestures—clearly addresses social communication processing in humans. Abstract does not state participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of participants observing social interaction (adult instructing child; child’s correct/incorrect actions) probing processing of others’ behavior—matches social cognition constructs. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and uses task-based fMRI. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI was performed during implicit and explicit processing of emotional facial expressions—a social communication task involving perception/understanding of others. fMRI study using a social interaction simulation probing friendship (type of relationship, emotional valence) in human participants (N=28). fMRI study of communicative speech (social communication) in 'normal subjects' reporting activation in social-cognitive regions.
